awd_titl_txt: James and Oasis de los Osos FSML Planning Grant
awd_abstract_narration:
The James and Oasis de los Osos Reserves encompass an elevation gradient that extends from mixed conifer woodlands at 5400 ft and to the Coachella Valley in the northwestern corner of the Colorado Desert at 200 ft above sea level. A component of intellectual merit derives from the longevity of prior research. Without preserving historic baseline data and continuing to monitor these sites, the long term effects of climate change and disturbed environment cannot be understood. Faculty, graduate students, STEM teachers, governmental agencies and Idyllwild community leaders, collaborate to provide classroom instruction and communication with nonscientists and the public. The goal is to share with the general public an increased understanding of ecological science, including its findings, applications and pursuit of new discoveries. The proposed strategic plan will guide integration of research, teaching and outreach while preserving the unique natural resources and scientific legacy of the James and Oasis de los Osos. 
  
This planning activity will develop a 5 year plan for the James San Jacinto Mountains and Oasis de los Osos Reserves, two of 39 Reserves in the University of California Natural Reserve system. The strategic plan will devise steps to increase research, training and educational outreach activities while minimizing the impact of those activities on the Reserves. The overarching goal is to maximize understanding and stewardship of the unique desert-to-mountain ecotone through scientific research and education of teachers, students and the general public. Recent improvements in reserve facilities and changes in personnel and use patterns at the James and Oasis de los Osos Reserves require new vision and strategic plan on order to address the needs of current and future stakeholders. These circumstances have created a need to seek external expertise to help identify additional infrastructural improvements necessary to support the increased overnight capacity; suggest programmatic directions that will take advantage of the new facilities and will complement and enhance existing academic programs and databases; and define appropriate development of Oasis de los Osos to allow increased use without compromising the environment.

por.por_cntn:
Expanded facilities and personnel structure (2012) at the James San Jacinto Mountains Reserve (est. 1966) required a planning grant in 2015. The major planning outcomes of this grant include developing Management Plans for the James and Oasis de los Osos Reserves and submission of a successful FSML grant for facilities improvement, and in order to meet deferred maintenance, we submitted a matching grant proposal to the Wildlife Conservation Board for California Proposition 68, Parks, Environment and Water bond. The major goals of the James San Jacinto Mountains and Oasis de los Osos Reserves were to 1) Identify additional infrastructural improvements necessary to support the increased overnight capacity (e.g. increased off-grid power, improved septic, etc.); 2) suggest programmatic directions that will take advantage of the new facilities and will complement and enhance existing academic programs and databases; 3) define sustainable and ecologically-friendly development of Oasis de los Osos to allow increased use without compromising the environment.

The planning grant advanced the capacity for research at both the James and Oasis de los Osos Reserves in the following ways:

The James Reserve user survey showed high levels of satisfaction with existing facilities and protocols. As a result of 3 planning workshops in 2015 and 2016, the FSML Planning Grant Committee recommended that I apply for additional funds for a new solar/battery installation to enhance research capacity. The steering committee encouraged the James to plan to improve our power infrastructure further by searching for new technologies to improve our off-grid power systems. Based on the results from this planning grant, the PI applied for another NSF FSML grant to double the photovoltaic battery bank. The James Reserve no longer relies on a backup propane generator. Off-grid power at the James Reserve is stable and with the additional PV batteries, even without continuously gathering solar energy (e.g., winter conditions), the station can run off of stored solar for a period of 72 hours The James Reserve now has sufficient power to support overnight use during the winter and at full capacity (over 70 people) as well as additional facilities, laboratories and instruments.

Since 1987 when UCR acquired Oasis de los Osos, it had very little research use in spite of its rich natural resources and high researcher interest in the area. In 2015-16, the steering committee met with stakeholders (Workshop II) who would be impacted by planning activities, e.g. Snow Creek homeowners, Bureau of Land Management, Wildlands Conservancy. In 2019, the James Reserve closed due to flooding (Feb. 14 – May 17, 2019). Efforts were refocused on Oasis de los Osos Reserve, where the PI conducted several outreach activities. As a result, UCR secured a one-million dollar bequest of a residence next to Oasis de los Oso, as well as a rare book collection of desert literature that is now curated at UC Riverside.

Through this planning grant, we identified areas of need for James Reserve and Oasis de los Osos that increase and broaden our ability to support research, teaching and outreach. Successful subsequent grants recommended by the planning grant committee resulted in acquiring new monitoring equipment and research. Extensions of this grant allowed for continued planning activities after wildfires, floods and the pandemic, including revised safety plans, more support from safety teams on campus at UCR, improved communications, and additional safety equipment, including survival provisions for 72 or more hours, a siren, ham radio, portable cell phone boosters and a megaphone and partial support for the first climate station at Oasis de los Osos, previously without facilities or equipment. These improvements allow for a more stable infrastructure, namely power, heat, water, and communications. This outcome will benefit greater society by generating more research opportunities to collect environmental data that will help us track environmental change.
